posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
What do you think is the best PvM duo in a given environment?

Obviously this varies wildly depending on the environment, I'm mainly interested in level 40 characters in low/medium magic worlds. The inspiration for this thread was a conversation I had about dual-logging in WoG, but I don't want to restrict the conversation to just the WoG server. I also don't want to focus on dual-logging, so the difficulty of playing both builds at once isn't an issue.

I think that the best PvM duo in a low/medium magic world is a Cler/RDD and Wiz/PM. The lower the magic level the better this duo does, in high magic worlds both builds are usually overshadowed by others due to available items. Offensive melee, offensive casting, defence, and healing are all covered between the two builds, while offensive ranged can be included by giving the Cler/RDD Zen Archery.
The level spread for the Cler/RDD is either Cler24/Bard2/RDD14 (for min-maxing AB), Cler26/Bard4/RDD10 (lower AB but better saves), or Cler28/Bard2/RDD10 (higher caster level). This build has Dev Crit (in environments where it is enabled), full Cleric casting, and can hit the +20 AB cap self-buffed. In some environments Divine Might and Divine Shield are worth taking, but in general focusing on STR is usually best. Zen Archery results in a mediocre ranged AB when fully buffed, depending on the environment it could be worth taking.
Example Cler/RDD: [dracolich-duo-d-cleric-28-bard-2-red-dr ... 55326.html]
The level spread for the Wiz/PM is either Rog2/Wiz28/PM10 (better skills) or Wiz29/PM10/Monk 1 (higher caster level and an extra feat). The main choice for this build is whether to be a CON based nuke mage or an INT based DC mage. Whether to build for AC or not is another important decision. It can reach 80ish AC in a +5 environment with IExp but if Expertise is disabled when casting then building for AC becomes less attractive. However, even if casting in Expertise is disabled the extra AC can be useful against hard hitting enemies so it might be worth taking anyway.
Example Wiz/PM: [dracolich-duo-l-rogue-2-wizard-28-pale- ... 55327.html]
The main strategy is for the Wiz/PM to tank while the Cler/RDD attacks. The Wiz/PM can either AC tank or DR tank, has damage shields for reciprocal damage, and can cast nuke spells while tanking. The Cler/RDD has over 65 AB self-buffed with Dev Crit, in addition to Harm, Heal, Word Of Faith, and several other useful spells. If melee doesn't work then the Wiz/PM can focus on using damage shields and nuke spells while the Cler/RDD heals the Wiz/PM. The Cler/RDD has a fairly high AB on the Harm/Heal touch attack so combining Mords and Harm/Heal is another no-save spell option. Both builds have access to UMD so support scrolls and wands can be used by both builds.

An honourable mention goes to Bard + DPS, this can be a very nasty combination and has a lot of room for customisation. Curse Song gives up to -2 AB, -7 AC, -2 Fort, and -18 skills. When combined with the -6 AC from Taunt even a mediocre DPS build can reliably land hits, Dev Crits, and successfully disarm or knockdown opponents.

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
It really does depend on the world and how it is “boxed”. But assuming you knew nothing about the next world beyond “it is a mid-low magic world” and you needed an persistent world “explorer duo”. I would probably go with a Dev-crit immune (resistant) melee tank and a buffer.

Meaning I would likely go with a deep cleric Trave/Trickery build with a sprinkling of monk and rogue in the epics (pull rogue level or two into preepic if needed) and a melee PM (Bd/PM/Fi] DevCrit build. After I worked out the nuances of the PW, this would change to fit how the world in question is boxed.

On Arelith I would go with a 30 sanc healer and a Fi/WM/Ro melee.

On WoG, a zenarchery 38 cleric and DevCrit/immune DevCrit melee.

On Blackstone a speed sorcerer and probably a battlecleric.


I default to cleric because under the Unmodded NwN it is the class that checks the most options and offers the most versatility without requiring anything other than mundane items. Not only does it check the most boxes and plugs the most holes for the cleric, it can check all those boxes and plug all those holes for a duo melee as well. On a low/mid magic world, melee characters are restricted by item availability and power. A cleric can and does generally does allow a buffed melee character to punch well above the weight offered by a low magic world and up into a mid to upper middle magic world in spells on mundane items. It also offers all the core spells generally needed to function outside of Mordekainen’s Disjunction.

A melee Pm does the same, but for Undispellable AC and the key immune DevCrit.

The caveat is I build for exploration survival until I learn the world. I tend to start on a new world with a battlecleric as a single explorer assuming you can sort out the deity rules quickly :)

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Great discussion.
I play a lot of party in mid magic these days and very interested in this.

I break down basic party jobs to:
- tank (actually the most important)
- buff
- damage
- skills (ie traps, detection, locks etc etc)
- disables / debilitate / healing

With only two party members, versatility is key

My top choices:
1. Human/dwarf Fighter / Bard / RDD or human Bard / Blackguard / RDD for the tank / DPS / Buffer.  Both Bard heavy (ie Bard 20+ for lasting inspiration), put dev crit if possible. Mogheiden for example (moghedien-melody-of-the-dark-bard-26-bg ... 50150.html).
2. Dex based Cleric/Rogue/SD, Wis based Cleric/Rogue/Monk zen archer, or wisdom Druid/Rogue/Monk with Dragon Shape. 

Both choices can do all the jobs listed above, just slightly differently.
1. can tank, buff, damage, skills, disables/debilitate (ie improved knockdown/curse song)
2. can tank, buff, damage, skills and disables/debilitate (ie stonehold), 

Beyond that I would start to add specialists into the mix.
Third choice is a CHA human sorcerer 35/paladin 2/rogue 3 to spam out bigby's, summons/black blades of disaster/mind blank/stoneskin/IGMS spam for more buffs/spellpower/great saves/more skills. Then sit in the background saving spells either invisible or greater sanctuaried. The other two can do heaps, just step in when things get hairy. Can use ShapeChange/Damage Shield to tank as well.

Fourth addition, would be a divine damage ultra high Arcane Archer like Mick Dagger's build, there is plenty of protection available for it, and if he dies just resurrect him.

Fifth final specialist would be some unkillable spell immune dex monk like Monk 38/Assassin 2 ala WebShaman style. Give him a pile of Mord's Scrolls to remove enemy Bigby's spells from your teammates (I think this works...) if the whole team suddenly gets ambushed by a pile of mages spamming Bigby's 9, you are immune, you use a greater sanctuary scroll, then those mord scrolls to remove the bigby's whilst running at the speed of light around any mobs that might be present.

But, aside from that...

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
My first character on any server is always a caster cleric so I can definitely see the benefits of a Cleric and Figh/Bard/PM duo. I can't speak for Arelith or WoG, but on BSK the best duo is probably a tank and DPS. Mages aren't that useful when it comes to bosses and battle clerics are overshadowed by dedicated melee builds due to +20 AB weapons being available.

Shifter and paladin is certainly a unique pair, it could work well on servers where most opponents are evil. As long as it has other shapes such as Risen Lord and Rakshasa then the shifter could also act as a decent tank while the paladin gets to smiting. High AB from paladin buffs and unblockable damage from Divine Might will work against a lot of mobs, even those with high AC or high DI/DR,

From the ones you listed I would go with a Bard/BG/RDD and zen caster Cleric. You'd have offensive melee, ranged, and casting capabilities, both can AC tank, and both builds would have a lot of flexibility due to UMD.

Levelling a pair of pure rogues would be a nice challenge, maybe one STR and one DEX to help with any sneak immune foes.

Monk/SD is definitely a good defensive build, but I would pair it up with an offensive build rather than having two of them. I've played and fought both Monk35/SD5s and Monk34/SD5/Rog1s in the past. Although their defences make them very hard to kill their weak offence means that they're more distractions than real threats, although with enough time 20s will wear down most opponents without Epic Dodge or regen. Having a build that can both AC tank and absorb spells would definitely be a great help to their party member though, they can run in, get aggro, and leave the killing to their party member. I would probably pair it with either an AA or a mage, but any offensive build will do really.

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
I suppose it depends on your assumptions. To use things like UMD and niche builds you need to understand the server you play on.

If UMD offers little or no advantage (Arelith) then all those builds relying on it become rubbish pretty quickly. Drop in server with defined rest areas or long rest windows and Divine builds become far less useful.

RDD builds are restricted on more servers than not, so I tend not to start there myself but I often end there :)

In my mind, niche builds are where you end up on a server or module once you know it. Generic “explore and learn” builds are a different thing.

I am enjoying reading people’s thoughts, approach and assumptions though, they are diverse and very interesting.

Thanks for the post!

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
Blackstone has +20 weapons and a level 40 cap. It is an interesting world where there are two progression tiers. The first is a mid tier magic world and the second is a high tier via crafting magic world.

Arelith is a heavily customised level 30 world with end game weapons hitting +3 with some racial and class limited weapons hitting +4. It is interesting because they have a version of NwN with some level of class balance. Whether or not the version is to your tastes is a different thing, but it is a solid attempt at creating what NwN and frankly D&D “should” have been.

Monks are weak offensively because they have to “Hit” stuff to damage it and even with more attacks and the UBAB attack schedule you are better off with fewer attacks that require less than a 20 to hit and critical. A 3/4 BAB class is weak offensively unless it has other mechanisms of bridging the AB vs AC gap and a monk has none ... no, circle kick is not an AB vs AC bridge ...

Now, to be fair, if the world is balanced for 3/4 BAB melee classes to hit end game NPCs then a monk does well. Or if you dip or multi them and net high BAB high number of attacks, the game changes.

But, compared to a full melee class a deep monk build is weak offensively. The trade off being they are exceedingly strong defensively.

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
InterestIngly, on a pure 3/4 BaB class with no way to mitigate the AB drop, whether circle kick or FoB nets full UBAB or not doesn’t make a difference outside of clearing the trash mobs. When you need a 20, you need a 20. And that is why monk is weak offensively. You get 2 or 3 extra 1/20 shots to hit over a straight melee who are steadily hitting 2 attacks (first and hasted) for more damage because they have enhancement bonuses (not Attack bonuses), decent threat ranges and critical multipliers and depending on how AC intensive the combat, let’s say 1/20 on the other 3 attacks.

So with a monk attacking 8 times a round using unarmed combat, FoB, circle kick and haste but requiring a 20 to hit will hit 0.4 times per round,

A straight melee attacking 5 times a round using a weapon and haste, but requiring a 15 to hit (25% on primary attack which is MUCH worst than most end game content is typically balanced) would hit .65 times per round.

A straight melee is typically considered to have a 10 AB differential over a 3/4 melee due to the 5 BaB differential and the extra fighter/CoT/WM feats, paladin spells and tighter stat focus (honestly not sure why on a blackguard ... hehe). Meaning when a monk needs a 15 to hit (-2 for FoB): 17/20/20/20/20/20/17/20 (also those extra free attacks of circle kick and haste are on BAB schedule not UBAB) a fighter/WM/CoT needs needs a 5 to hit: 5/10/15/20/5.

And lets be clear, no “decent” server is end game boss balanced for a 3/4 melee class with limited feats for stat bumps hitting 25% of the time at full BAB. You would be lucky to see 10% of the full BAB attack.

So a monk will hit .6 times per round and a pure melee will hit 2.3 times per round. There really is no comparison until both need straight 20s or they both need 1s.

Where a monk pulls ahead is it can sometimes survive longer, particularly solo. And dead is 0 hits per round so .6 hits per round wins :)

This is why a monk is weak offensively but very effective trash mob sweepers. It is also why they can solo end game mobs on certain servers. When everyone needs a 20, more attacks is better and not much can outlast a monk.

For what it is worth, the damage per hit math is worse. Most full melee can out damage an entire monk (fist) attack sequence connecting with 1-2 hits.

This is why monks are weak offensively. It is also why bards need bard song, curse song and taunt to function in melee.

Monks, from a melee offence perspective become quite interesting when you dip them however ... this also erases most of their defensive capabilities.

Now, back to my DD/monk/rogue unarmed FoB / Circle kick EDR build. If you want to use all those mob attacks you need to mitigate the 20s!

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
I don't play on Arelith but I do play on Blackstone Keep, which has +20 AB weapons not +20 EB weapons. Whenever I post builds on the ECB forums they are built with +5EB/+5AC worlds in mind, since in my experience those are the most common when it comes to item properties.

Monk35/SD5 and Monk34/SD5/Rog1 are two of the best defensive builds in NWN, but their offence is terrible when compared to proper DPS builds even in a +5 EB world. The damage on a Monk/SD is mediocre for a DEXer in a +5 EB world, but the AB is bad even if you drop defensive feats for AB feats. I care about self-buffed AB more than the base AB that the ECB focuses on, but +50 AB is the absolute minimum I would accept for a melee build in a +5 EB world. +50 AB is barely acceptable in a +5 EB world, I would class decent AB as above +60 AB. There are plenty of ways to increase AB beyond just adding AA, RDD, or WM levels in a low/medium magic world.

Let's compare two minmaxed DEX builds with Epic Dodge, Monk35/SD5 and Rog13/Figh8/WM19. I'll assume +12 STR, +12 DEX, and +5 AB/EB.

Monk35/SD5
When I build this I go for 61 SR with Armor Skin, Epic Dodge, and ISR8, but for this comparison I'll drop Armor Skin and one ISR feat for EWF: Unarmed and Epic Prowess. The starting stats are 16STR/20DEX for an elf and 14STR/20DEX for a halfling.
Elf AB: 25 (BAB) + 16 (DEX) + 4 (Feats) + 5 (AB Bonus) = +50 (+48 with Flurry)
Elf Damage: 1d20 + 9 (19-20/x2)
Average Hit: 19.5 / Average Crit: 39
Halfling AB: 25 (BAB) + 16 (DEX) + 4 (Feats) + 5 (AB Bonus) + 1 (Size Bonus) = +51 (+49 with Flurry)
Halfling Damage: 2d12 + 8 (19-20/x2)
Average Hit: 21 / Average Crit: 42

Rog13/Figh8/WM19
A kukri-wielding halfling with 12STR/20DEX starting stats. For the sake of fairness I'll ignore the +7d6 Sneak Attack and assume that the kukri isn't keened.
AB: 29 (BAB) + 19 (DEX) + 4 (Feats) + 4 (WM Bonus) + 5 (EB Bonus) + 1 (Size) = +62
Damage: 1d4 + 18 (13-20/x3)
Average Hit: 20.5 / Average Crit: 61.5

The Monk35/SD5 has -11/-12 AB, lower average criticals, and a lower threat range, but has similar average non-crit damage and potentially +2 APR in comparison to the Rog13/Figh8/WM19. If the Rog/WM is built for dual-wielding then the APR will be the same for both builds, although the offhand non-crit damage will be slightly worse than the Monk/SD damage. Unless both builds are rolling for 20s the Rog/WM will outdamage the Monk/SD against most opponents. This is just comparing two DEX builds with Epic Dodge, once I start including builds like STR Clerics and STR WMs then the Monk35/SD5 is completely overshadowed in terms of both AB and damage.

I've never played on WoG but I imagine that most of your time fighting big bosses with a Monk/SD is spent watching the screen in boredom waiting for 20s since the bosses can't hit you and you can't hit them. Imagine how much faster you would kill bosses if your Monk/SD was partnered with a STR WM, Divine Might AA, or nuke mage. That's why having one Monk/SD in your duo would work but having two of them would be a bad idea.

Edit: I just noticed that I wrote the halfling's unarmed damage as 2d12 rather than 2d6, as  a result the halfling does even less damage compared to the other two builds.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Builds should be adapted to their environments, so if it works on WoG then it's a good build for you. AC tanks are useless against bosses on BSK and a Monk/SD doesn't have the damage to be a DPS build either so it wouldn't do well in PvM.

In general the main problem with the build's offence is the low AB, especially when compared to proper offensive melee builds. In a +5EB environment the damage is okay for a DEXer, but again when compared to proper offensive melee builds it's lacking.

Maybe the WoG bosses just have lower AB and AC than I thought they would have. In a +5EB/+5AC world I would expect most high end PvM mobs to have around +50-+75 AB and 50-80 AC, depending on the type of mobs and whether they're bosses or not. On top of that most bosses would have some combination of concealment, DI/DR, immunities, regeneration, spells, and other nasty tricks that builders love to include. On the low/medium magic servers I've played on in the past the Monk/SD would need to be in IExp when fighting most high end bosses which would reduce the AB even further. If you can tank bosses on WoG without Expertise then I can see why you don't see a problem with the offence.

Personally I would still pick an offensive build as a partner though, having two AC tanks seems redundant to me.
